*G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28*.proposition: Under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and *G.L. c. 209C, § 20*, the Court may modify a custody order upon a showing of a **material and substantial change** and that modification serves the **best interests of the child**.

*G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20*.proposition: Under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and *G.L. c. 209C, § 20*, the Court may modify a custody order upon a showing of a **material and substantial change** and that modification serves the **best interests of the child**.

*G.L. c. 215,* \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 6.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of this Court pursuant to *G.L. c. 215,* §§ 3 and 6, and *G.L. c. 208,* § 28.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Since entry of the original custody Judgment, there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** affecting the best interests of the minor child, warranting modification under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and established case law, including *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and *Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 131 (2009).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: Custody of Kali is not a G.L. c. 208, § 28 modification case and does not apply or elaborate the “material and substantial change in circumstances” standard. Instead, it involves an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), focusing on the best interests of the child and the statutory factors for nonmarital children. The court expressly declines to apply the modification/substantial-change standard, so the case does not support the proposition that such a change exists warranting modification under c. 208, § 28.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Since entry of the original custody Judgment, there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** affecting the best interests of the minor child, warranting modification under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and established case law, including *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and *Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 131 (2009).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a modification case under § 28. The decision articulates the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and discusses how relocation with joint physical custody may constitute a substantial change under the ALI Principles, but the SJC does not hold or apply the Massachusetts § 28 “material and substantial change in circumstances” threshold for modifying custody. It therefore does not provide direct authority for the proposition that such a material and substantial change has occurred under § 28.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising…’ … ‘(4)… the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests….’”

*Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 75 Mass. App..proposition: Since entry of the original custody Judgment, there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** affecting the best interests of the minor child, warranting modification under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and established case law, including *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and *Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 131 (2009).
*Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 75 Mass. App..support_reasoning: This opinion is a divorce/custody/removal appeal decided in the first instance under G.L. c. 208, § 30 (removal) and best-interests principles; it is not a post‑judgment modification case under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The court does not apply or discuss the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard governing modification of an existing custody judgment, but instead reviews whether the trial judge correctly determined initial custody and removal. Thus, Prenaveau does not provide authority for the specific § 28 modification proposition cited.
*Prenaveau v. Prenaveau*, 75 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The custody issues in this case are bound up with the husband’s request to remove the children from the Commonwealth. Pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30… How the best interests of the children are to be measured, however, varies somewhat with the particular context presented… We therefore remand the custody and removal issues to the Probate and Family Court for such an assessment. In the interim, the children are to be returned to Massachusetts given that G. L. c. 208, § 30, prohibits removal except ‘upon cause shown.’”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Plaintiff’s proposed modification seeks to protect the child’s welfare and educational stability, consistent with the “best interest of the child” standard as articulated in *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001), and *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies the Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ framework to a relocation/modification dispute and emphasizes that custody and removal decisions must be guided by the child’s welfare, including educational stability and overall well-being. While the case is not about a plaintiff’s “proposed modification” in the abstract, it holds that modification and relocation determinations must be evaluated under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and § 30 with a focus on the child’s welfare and stability, and it reverses orders that failed to properly weigh those best‑interest factors. Thus it is fair, though somewhat generalized, support for a proposition that a modification grounded in protecting welfare and educational stability is consistent with the best‑interests standard.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ … ‘The uprooting of a child … should be done only for compelling reasons.’ … [T]he criteria for determining such best interests were set out in Hale v. Hale… and Yannas….”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The Plaintiff’s proposed modification seeks to protect the child’s welfare and educational stability, consistent with the “best interest of the child” standard as articulated in *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001), and *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn is centrally about the impact of domestic violence on custody determinations and the need for explicit findings about how such violence affects the child when applying the best-interest standard. It does not discuss or emphasize protecting a child’s educational stability or school continuity as a distinct component of the best-interest analysis. Thus, while it supports a general best-interest framework with a focus on safety from domestic violence, it does not provide authority for the specific notion that a modification promoting educational stability is consistent with that standard.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child… We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that interference with a child’s schooling or disregard for educational responsibilities constitutes a material change warranting modification.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct-appeal divorce/custody decision and does not involve a post-judgment modification proceeding or any discussion of what constitutes a ‘material change in circumstances.’ While the court notes that the parents disagreed about schooling and other child-rearing issues, that disagreement is analyzed solely in determining the initial custody allocation, not as a material change justifying modification of an existing order. Thus, it does not support the proposition that interference with schooling or educational responsibilities is a recognized material change warranting modification.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education, as well as in day-to-day decision making and philosophy of discipline, an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that interference with a child’s schooling or disregard for educational responsibilities constitutes a material change warranting modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/custody decision focusing on relocation to Greece and the ‘real advantage’ standard. It does not discuss interference with schooling or disregard of educational responsibilities as a material change warranting modification, nor does it address modification standards at all. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed proposition.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life) ...

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that interference with a child’s schooling or disregard for educational responsibilities constitutes a material change warranting modification.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with an initial custody determination and parental visitation, focusing broadly on the child’s emotional and physical welfare and parental conflict over philosophical instruction. It does not discuss school attendance, interference with schooling, or disregard of educational responsibilities as a material change justifying modification of an existing order. It also does not frame any change in circumstances in terms of education, so it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized that interference with a child’s schooling or disregard for educational responsibilities constitutes a material change warranting modification.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns relocation and paternity under G.L. c. 209C, not modification based on interference with schooling or educational responsibilities. Nothing in the concurrence (or the described holding) discusses school-related conduct as a material change of circumstances, nor does it address modification standards in that context. Using this case to claim Massachusetts courts have repeatedly recognized interference with schooling as a material change misstates its subject and holding.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. … This is not a removal case, and Yannas is inapposite.”

*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: The modification sought herein aligns with the child’s best interests by promoting stability, academic progress, and consistent routines, consistent with *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), and *Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).
*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: Pierce v. Pierce is an alimony modification case focused on a payor spouse’s voluntary retirement and the statutory alimony factors; it does not concern custody, parenting plans, or the child’s best interests, nor does it discuss stability, academic progress, or children’s routines. Using Pierce to support a child‑focused ‘best interests’ proposition mischaracterizes its subject matter and holding, which are about balancing financial needs and the ability to pay between former spouses. The case therefore does not provide authority for the proposition stated.
*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “In conducting this multifactor analysis, whether in fashioning the original alimony judgment or in modifying that judgment, the judge must weigh all the statutory factors in light of the facts of the particular case; no single factor is determinative.… ‘the statutory authority of a court to award alimony continues to be grounded in the recipient spouse’s need for support and the supporting spouse’s ability to pay.’”

Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Jessica Martin, and pursuant to *Massachusetts General Laws* c. 208, § 28, c. 209C, § 20, and applicable caselaw, respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the Judgment of Custody and Parenting Time entered on **April 15, 2022**, in the above-captioned matter.
